content.text: Java syntax is the set of rules and conventions for writing Java programs. A Java program typically consists of one or more classes that define the objects and methods that make up the program.
Comments are non-executable statements in Java used to provide explanations or annotations within the code. Java supports single-line and multi-line comments.

Data types in Java specify the size and type of values that can be stored in variables. Java has two categories of data types: primitive types (e.g., int, boolean) and reference types (e.g., String, Arrays).
Variables are containers for storing data values. In Java, each variable is associated with a data type.
Operators in Java are special symbols that perform operations on variables and values. Java provides a rich set of operators including arithmetic, relational, and logical operators.
Control structures control the flow of execution in a program. Java supports various control structures, including if-else statements, switch statements, and loops (for, while, do-while).
Arrays in Java are a powerful data structure that can store multiple values of the same type. Arrays are indexed, with the first element's index being 0.
Methods in Java are blocks of code that perform a specific task and are executed when they are called. Methods can take parameters and can also return a value.
